data.description: The child’s details and contact information.
The full name of the patient. This will normally be given by a Patient Demographics Service (PDS) patient trace, or the name of the patient held on the local Patient Administration System (PAS).
The name by which the patient wishes to be addressed.
The date of birth of the patient.
The town and country of birth of the patient.
As the patient wishes to portray themselves.
The patient’s phenotypic sex. This determines how the patient will be treated clinically.
The unique identifier for a patient within the NHS in England and Wales.

Country specific or local identifier such as

Community Health Index (CHI) in Scotland.
The patient’s usual place of residence.
Telephone contact details of the patient. To include mobile, work and home number if available.
The email address of the patient.
The preferred contact method such as sign language, letter or phone.Also the preferred written communication format such as large print, braille.
The ethnicity of the patient.
The religious affiliation as specified by the patient.
The history of the child’s demographic details and contact information.

Any previous names, aliases and preferred name. This will normally be given by a Patient Demographics Service (PDS) patient trace or the name of the patient held on the local Patient Administration System (PAS).
History of date of birth changes.
History of gender change.
History of patient’s usual place of residence.
History of telephone contact details of the patient. To include such as mobile, work and home number if available.
The Individual requirements of the child such as communication, cultural, cognitive or mobility needs.
An indicator of whether the individual requirement relates to the child or their primary carer.
The Individual requirements of the person. These may be communication, cultural, cognitive or mobility needs relating to themselves or their primary carer.
Outlines capability and support required in order to provide accessibility, with regard to disability.
Requirement for a communication professional to be present in order to provide accessibility, with regard to disability.

children.title: Accessible information- requires specific contact method

data.description: Requirement for a specific contact method in order to provide accessibility, with regard to disability.

children.title: Accessible information- requires specific information format

data.description: Requires information in a specific format in order to provide accessibility, with regard to disability.
A child or their primary carer’s potential physical movement between two spaces that achieves participation and a degree of independence.
An indicator of cognitive impairment to be considered when communicating related to the child or their primary carer.
The details of the GP practice where the child is registered.
Where the patient or patient's representative offers the name of a GP as their usual GP.
The name and address of the patient's registered GP practice.
The identifier of the registered GP practice.
Indication that the parent/carer or child has opted out of registering with a GP.
The birth details of the baby.
The date and time of birth of the baby.
The place of birth (including the address and organisation name where relevant).
The type of place in which the baby was born (e.g. private health facility, domestic address, NHS hospital, midwifery led unit etc. )
The sequence in which this baby was born (one of one, one of two etc)
Where the baby is one of a multiple birth, include the total number of offspring and include whether the baby is identical to one of the siblings.
Gestational age in weeks and days (usually equivalent to length of pregnancy).
Type of delivery for the baby such as vacuum extraction, breech extraction or elective caesarean section.
The type(s) of delivery for the baby that was attempted, but was not the final delivery method.
The numeric value for weight at birth.
Problems experienced by the baby during delivery such as cord prolapse, meconium aspiration, fetal distress.
Physical problems identified with the baby at, or shortly after, birth. For example cleft lip/palate, extensive bruising, cephalohematoma.

A set of observations carried out on the baby following birth to check adaptation to life outside the womb.

This includes 1 minute, 5 minutes and 10 minute observations.
The details of any neonatal resuscitation measures required such as chest compression, oxygen mask.
The length of time between delivery of the baby and the time spontaneous respiration began.
Whether or not the baby was put to the breast.
Maternal medical conditions or infectious diseases arising in pregnancy which may have an impact on the fetus such as gestational diabetes, rubella.
Problems with the fetus diagnosed with screening or ultrasound. e.g. Down syndrome, congenital heart disease.
The details of each instance of the National screening programmes.

The details of each instance of a Newborn Blood Spot Screening entryThe details are captured as part of the NBS programme which screens for sickle cell disease (SCD), cystic fibrosis (CF), congenital hypothyroidism (CHT) and inherited metabolic diseases (IMDs).
The date on which the blood spot test was completed.
The details of the professional performing the blood spot screening (including name and role).
The date on which the blood spot card was received in the Lab (01 outcome code).
The unique identifier of the laboratory undertaking blood spot screening.
The date that a Blood Spot Test outcome (status) was received by a Health Care Provider from the testing laboratory per test performed.
The details of the individual blood spot tests performed for each of the 9 conditions that could be tested.
The outcome of the screening tests performed for each of the 9 conditions.
Supporting text may be given covering regarding the screening test, outcome and actions taken.

The details of each instance of a Newborn hearing screening entry.These details are captured as part of the NHSP programme which offers two types of test for babies:automated otoacoustic emission (AOAE)
      
        
      
    
    
      
      automated auditory brainstem response (AABR)
The date on which the Newborn Hearing Screening was performed.
The details of the professional performing the newborn hearing screening (including name and role).
The type of hearing screening test performed.
The screening test result of each of the individual hearing tests performed.
The overall outcome of the newborn hearing screening.
Supporting text may be given covering regarding the screening test, outcome and actions taken.

children.title: Newborn and infant physical examination (72 hours)

data.description:
The details of each instance of a Newborn and Infant Physical Examination (72 hours) entry.The details are captured as part of the NIPE programme which tests babies within 72 hours of birth for conditions relating to their:heart
      
        
      
    
    
      
      hips
      
        
      
    
    
      
      eyes
      
        
      
    
    
      
      testes
The date on which the Newborn and Infant Physical Examination Screening was performed.

The details of the professional performing the infant physical examination

(including name and role).
The details of where the examination was performed.
The type of infant physical examination test performed.
The screening test outcome of each of the infant physical examination tests performed.
Supporting text may be given covering regarding the screening test, outcome and actions taken.

children.title: Newborn and infant physical examination (6-8 Weeks)

data.description:
The details of each instance of a Newborn and Infant Physical Examination (6-8 weeks) entry.The details captured as part of the NIPE programme which tests babies again at 6-8 weeks for conditions relating to their:heart
      
        
      
    
    
      
      hips
      
        
      
    
    
      
      eyes
      
        
      
    
    
      
      testes
The date on which the Newborn and Infant Physical Examination was performed
The details of the professional performing the infant physical examination (including name and role) .
The details of where the examination was performed .
The type of infant physical examination test performed.

The screening test outcome of each of the infant physical examination tests performed
    .
Supporting text may be given covering regarding the screening test, outcome and actions taken.
The details of the individual or team who referred the child.
The date of referral.

The name, role,

organisation and contact details of referrer.If not an individual, this could be a GP surgery, department, specialty, sub-specialty, educational establishment or mental health service.This should also include the source of the referral such as self-referral.

The form in which a referral is sent and received.This could be one of the following;letter
    
    
      email
    
    
      
        transcript of a telephone conversation


        
      
    
    
      
        Choose and book


        
      
    
    
      
        inpatient (self-referral)


        
      
    
    
      
        unknown

The type of service or team that the patient has been referred into for example;GP surgery


        
      
    
    
      
        department


        
      
    
    
      
        specialty


        
      
    
    
      
        subspecialty


        
      
    
    
      educational establishment
    
    
      
        mental health
The type of service or team that the patient has been referred from.
Referrer’s assessment of urgency (e.g. urgent, soon, routine).

A clear statement giving the reason for referral.This may include;diagnosis
    
    
      treatment
    
    
      
        transfer of care due to relocation


        
      
    
    
      
        investigation


        
      
    
    
      
        second opinion


        
      
    
    
      management of the patient (e.g. palliative care)
    
    
      provide referrer with advice/guidance
      
        
      
    
    
      carer’s concerns
The details of the child’s admission.
The date and time the patient was admitted to hospital.
The ODS site code and description of where the child was admitted.
The name and designation of the consultant who has overall responsibility for the patient (may not actually see the patient).
Specialties designated by royal colleges and faculties. E.g. orthopaedics, renal medicine, endocrinology, etc.

Where the patient was immediately prior to admission such as;Please use national code from the NHS Data Dictionary.usual place of residence


        
      
    
    
      
        temporary place of residence


        
      
    
    
      
        penal establishment
Identify others accompanying the patient such asa relative, friend, patient, informal carer or advocate.If the patient was not present please give details of any authorised representative.

The health problems and issues experienced by the patient that prompted the decision to admit them to hospital such as chest pain, mental health crisis, blackout, fall,

a specific procedure, intervention, investigation or treatment, non compliance with treatment.
How the patient was admitted to hospital. For example: elective, emergency, maternity, transfer etc.
The details of the child’s discharge.
The actual date and time of discharge.
The ODS site code and description of where the discharge was from.
The consultant responsible for the patient at the time of discharge.
The specialty or department responsible for the patient at the time of discharge.

The method of discharge from hospital.National codes such as:patient discharged on clinical advice or with clinical consent


        
      
    
    
      
      
        patient discharged him/herself or was discharged by a relative or advocate


        
      
    
    
      
      patient died
    
    
      
      stillbirth
The destination of the patient on discharge.National codes such as High Dependency Unit.
The address to which patient discharged.Only completed where this is not the usual place of residence.
The details of baby’s measurements
The date the measurement was recorded.
The location where the measurement was recorded.
The details of the professional performing the measurement including their name and role.
The numerical value for weight.
The numeric value for the body length.
The child’s BMI centile calculated using the height, weight, gender and the age of the child.
The numerical value for the head circumference.

The details of each instance of a 
    National Child Measurement Programme
    
       entry
The date on which the measurement was recorded.

The school where the measurement was recorded
    .

Record of the school year the child was in at the time of the measurement (Reception or Year 6)
    .
Numeric value for weight.
Numeric value for height.

Reason for child being withdrawn from the measurement as part of the National Child Measurement Programme
    .
The details of a baby’s feeding status.
The date the feeding status was recorded.
Whether or not the baby's first feed was breast milk.

children.title: Milk feeding status of the baby

data.description:
Whether the baby is totally breast milk fed, partially breast milk fed


















or not breast milk fed. To be recorded each time a baby has contact with a health professional.
A record of the predominant feeding method for the baby such as breast fed, bottle/cup fed, gastrostomy, nasogastric feeds etc.
Date of last breast milk feed to the nearest month and year.

Whether the baby has been introduced to solid foods at the time seen
    .
A record of any concerns about the baby’s feeding.
The details of any known allergies, intolerances or adverse reactions.
The date that the reaction was clinically recorded/asserted. This will often equate to the date of onset of the reaction but this may not be wholly clear from source data.

The agent

such as food, drug or substances that has caused or may cause an allergy, intolerance or adverse reaction in this patient.
When the reaction was first experienced. May be a date of partial date (e.g. year) or text (e.g. during childhood).
A description of the manifestation of the allergic or adverse reaction experienced by the patient. For example, skin rash.
A description of the severity of the reaction.
A description of the certainty that the stated causative agent caused the allergic or adverse reaction.
The type of reaction experienced by the patient (allergic, adverse, intolerance).
Results of investigations that confirmed the certainty of the diagnosis. Examples might include results of skin prick allergy tests.
Probability of the reaction (allergic, adverse, intolerant) occurring.
Any additional comment or clarification about the allergy or adverse reaction
Information on illness in family relations relevant to the health or care of the child.
The date the family history was recorded.
The condition or diagnosis in family relations deemed to be significant to the care or health of the child.
The relationship of the patient with the condition to the child.
Record of whether the condition or diagnosis was on the mother’s or father’s side of the family, where needed e.g. paternal grandfather.
Any further textual comment.
The details of a Childs Immunisations.
The details of the professional performing the immunisation (including name and role)
The details of where the immunisation was performed.
The date on which the Immunisation was administered.
Which immunisation has been administered (SNOMED CT code – list of available immunisations).
Vaccine product administered.
The vaccine manufacturer.
The batch number of the vaccine.
Body site vaccine was administered into.
How vaccine entered the body.
Amount of vaccine administered.
Nominal position in a series of vaccines.
Whether the vaccine was administered or not, including the reason why
A flag to indicate the information was reported to a healthcare professional
The clinical indication or reason for administering the immunisation
The details of and instructions for medications and medical equipment the child is using.
The details of the professional administering the Medication (including name and role).
The details of where the Medication was administered.
The date on which the Medication was administered.
May be generic name or brand name (as appropriate).
Form of the medicinal substance e.g. capsules, tablets, liquid.

Medication administration description (oral, IM, IV, etc.): may include method of administration, (e.g. by infusion, via nebuliser, via NG tube) and/or site of use, (e.g. ‘to wound’, ‘to left eye’, etc.).
A single plain text phrase describing the entire medication dosage and administration directions, including dose quantity and medication frequency
How long to continue dose including do not discontinue. Coded text.

Allows for:* requirements for adherence support such as compliance aids, prompts and packaging requirements* additional information about specific medicines such as where specific brand required* patient requirements such as unable to swallow tablets.
Reason for medication being prescribed, where known.
The status of this prescription in an ambulatory (outpatient/GP/community) context.
The date and/or time that the medication course should begin.
The date and/or time that the medication course should finish.
Suggestions about duration and/or review, on-going monitoring requirements, advice on starting, discontinuing or changing medication.
The record of dietary supplements, dressings and equipment that the patient is currently taking or using.
The details of the childs emergency care attendance
Date and time patient arrived at the unscheduled care unit.
The details of where the unscheduled care attendance took place .
Source of referral for Unscheduled care

The health problem or issue experienced by the patient resulting in their attendance. This may include disease state, medical condition, response and reactions to therapies. E.g., blackout, dizziness, chest pain, follow up from admission, falls, a specific procedure, investigation or treatment.
Confirmed diagnosis; active diagnosis being treated. Include the stage of the disease where relevant.
The therapeutic or diagnostic procedure performed on the patient. This may be coded, or represented as free text.
The destination of the patient on discharge. National codes. E.g., High Dependency Unit.
Patient status on discharge from emergency care.
The actual date and time of discharge.
Safety Alerts at the Emergency Care Attendance suggested to be pulled through from the Safety Alerts heading.
A simple free text description of the plan of action following the contact with the child. This may include actions for the parent, healthcare professional (e.g. health visitor) and review.

Identify others accompanying the patient such as relative, friend, patient informal carer, advocate.If the patient was not present, was an authorised representative present. Include name and

relationship (friend, relative, etc.)
A description detailing a patient’s reason for attendance, results from the diagnostic and treatment process.
The details of Childs Personal Contacts
The name of the patient.
he patiental relationship the individual has to the child (e.g. father, grandmother, family friend etc.)
Flag to indicate whether the patiental contact has parental responsibility.
Contact details of the patient (e.g. telephone number, email address etc.)
The NHS number of the patiental contact .
The details of Childs professional contacts.
The name of the patient or the team responsible.
The professional role the individual has in relation to the child (e.g. Nursery Nurse, Health Visitor, School Nurse etc.).
The speciality of the professional responsible (e.g. Health Visiting, School Nursing etc.).
The name of the team, if the name of the patient has been entered.
The name of the Organisation responsible.
Contact details of the patient (e.g. telephone number, email address etc.).
The start date of the relationship with the health professional.
The end date of the relationship with the health professional.

The social setting in which the child lives,

such as their household, occupational history, and lifestyle factors.
Family and Household details of Social Context.
The details of those living in the same household and their relationship with the child.
People deemed as key by family and or Health Care Professional in the child's life that do not live in the home (s).
Factors in the household(s) which impact the child’s health and wellbeing, to include smoking in the home, alcohol/substance use etc.
The highest educational qualification attained by the child’s mother.
An indication of the type of accommodation where the child lives. This should be based on the main or permanent residence.
The employment status of the Mother and her occupation.

The employment status of the Father and his occupation
    .

Whether or not any household member had/has social services support
    .
Personal details of Social Context.
The record of the child’s social background, network and patiental circumstances such as housing, religious, ethnic/spiritual needs and social concerns.
The record of lifestyle choices made by the child which are pertinent to his or her health and well-being such as the record of the physical activity level, pets, hobbies, sexual habits etc.
Latest or current smoking status of the child.
Latest or current alcohol consumption record of the child.
Record of any drug/substance use by the child.
Detail of the Childs Educational History
Name of Educational establishment.
Phase/Type of Education establishment.
The year the child attended the school from.
The year the child left the school.
The outcome of an educational assessment.
The type of special educational needs for the child.
A list of the child’s diagnoses.
A date or estimated date of the Diagnosis.
The diagnosis or symptom identified.
The stage of the disease where relevant.
Supporting text may be given covering diagnosis confirmation, active diagnosis being treated.
A record of any information or advice given for the child, carer or relevant third party.
The details of the professional giving the information and advice (including name and role).
The details of where the information and advice was given.
The date on which the information and advice was given.

This includeswhat information (including health promotional messages)to whom it was given.The oral or written information or advice given to the patient, carer, other authorised representative, care professional or other third party. May include advice about actions related to medicines or other ongoing care activities on an ‘information prescription’. State here if there are concerns about the extent to which the patient and/or carer understands the information provided about diagnosis, prognosis and treatment.
The details of any risks the child poses to themselves or others.
The date on which the safety alert was recorded.
The location where the safety alert was recorded.
The details of the professional recording the safety alert (including name and role).
Risks the patient poses to themselves such as suicide, overdose, self-harm, self-neglect.
Risks to care professionals or others.
The details of where an adult or child is at risk from an identified patient e.g. family member etc.
Legal information of child
The named local authority.
Start date of a 'looked after child'

children.title: End date of a looked after child'

data.description: End date of a looked after child'
Start date of a child protection plan
End date of a child protection plan
Whether the child is at high risk of clinical deterioration, any relevant clinical risk factors and risk mitigation plans.
The date which the clinical risk factor was recorded.
The location where the clinical risk factor was recorded.
The details of the professional recording the clinical risk factor (including name and role) .
Factor that have been shown to be associated with the development of a medical condition being considered as a diagnosis. E.g. being overweight, smoker, no use of sun screen, enzyme deficiency.
Specific risk assessments required/undertaken.
Action taken to reduce the clinical risk.
The details of planned investigations, procedures and treatment, and whether this plan has been agreed with the child or their legitimate representative.

The date on which the Plan and Requested Actions was recorded
    .
The details of the professional performing the Plan and Requested Actions (including name and role).

A simple free text description of the plan of action following the contact with the child. This may include actions for the parent, child, healthcare professional (e.g. health visitor) and review details.
A brief description of the encounter.
The date on which the professional summary was recorded.
The location where the professional summary was recorded.
The details of the professional performing the professional summary (including name and role)
Summary of the encounter. Where possible, very brief. This may include interpretation of findings and results, opinion and specific action(s). Planned actions will be recorded under ‘plan’.
A summary of the problems that require investigation or treatment.
A date or estimated date that the Problem began.
Summary of problems that require investigation or treatment. This would include significant examination findings which are likely to have relevance, yet are not a diagnosis.

Any further textual comment to clarify,

such as statement that information is partial or incomplete.
The comments of the Parent\Guardian\Person.
Date the comment was entered and shared.
Who recorded the comment and what relationship they are to the child.
Free text comment made by the parent / guardian of the child, or the child themselves.
The details of Childs Assessment Scales
The date on which the assessment scale was recorded.
The location where the assessment scale was recorded.
The details of the professional performing the assessment scale (including name and role).
The name of the overarching assessment scale used e.g. Bayley, Griffiths, Ages & Stages Questionnaire etc.
The total global score from the assessment.
The name of the subscale used (where relevant).
he total subscale score from the assessment.
Supporting text may be given regarding the assessment scale as a whole or a subscale.
Examination finding details of Child
The date on which the examination was recorded.
The location where the examination was recorded.
The details of the professional performing the examination (including name and role).

children.title: Health and Wellbeing Assessment and Review

data.description: The specific review the examination was carried out at if necessary adhoc review can be used.

The examination performed such as general appearance, vital signs, mental state, head and neck examination, oral examination, cardiovascular system, respiratory system, abdomen, genitourinary, nervous system, musculoskeletal system, skin.This could include site and must include laterality where applicable.
The record of findings from the examinations performed.
Developmental Skills of the Child.
The name of the developmental skill (e.g. Walks independently, smiles, finger feeds etc).

The date the developmental skill was first achieved (developmental first) as reported by the parent. This is primarily for parent reporting as part of parent child health record at the time the skill is acquired.
The date the parent or carer was asked by a health professional about the developmental skill (milestone).
Whether the developmental skill was achieved, not achieved or equivocal.
The date a health professional observed or tested a developmental skill (milestone).
Whether the developmental skill was achieved, not achieved or equivocal.
Supporting text may be given regarding the developmental skill.

title: Health and Wellbeing Assessment and Reviews

data.description: Health and Wellbeing Assessment and Review details of the Child
Post Birth Review details of the Child.These are details of checks and assessments done on the baby prior to leaving hospital that do not make up the NIPE screening .

The date on which the Post Birth Review was recorded
    .

The location where the Post Birth Review. was recorded
    .
The details of the professional performing the Post Birth Review (including name and role) .
A list of examinations and assessments and their results carried out prior to discharge from hospital.
This includes what information (including health promotional messages) and to whom it was given from the Information and Advice Given heading.

To identify problems with the baby prior to discharge, which may include reasons for admission to a neonatal intensive care unit (NICU), including respiratory distress, neonatal fits, hypothermia, feeding difficulties etc.

Supporting text may be given covering regarding the outcome




















of the checks and actions taken.
New Baby Review details of child
The date on which the New Baby Review was recorded.
The location where the New Baby Review was recorded.
The details of the professional performing the New Baby Review (including name and role).
Weight of the baby at the New Baby Review, suggested to be pulled through from the Measurements heading.
Examinations Findings, from the Examination Findings heading. This includes physical and developmental examinations and checks.
Feeding status of the baby at the New Baby Review, from the Feeding Status heading.
Household environment at the New Baby Review, from the Social Context heading.

Safety Alerts at the New Baby Review,




















from the Safety Alerts heading.
This includes what information (including health promotional messages) and to whom it was given from the Information and Advice Given heading.

Summary of problems that require investigation or treatment. This would include significant examination findings which are likely to have relevance, yet are not a diagnosis, from the Problems and Issues heading
    .

Commentary to capture how mother and family are coping and any concerns about babies health or behaviour documented at the New Baby Review
    .

The details of 
      
    
    6-8 week Health Visitor Review
    
       .
The date on which the 6-8 HV week review was recorded.

The location where the 6-8 week HV review was recorded
    .
The details of the professional performing the 6-8 Week HV review (including name and role).
Weight of the baby at the 6-8 week HV review, suggested to be pulled through from the Measurements heading.
Examinations Findings, from the Examination Findings heading. This includes physical and developmental examinations and checks.
Head Circumference of the baby at the 6-8 week HV review, suggested to be pulled through from the Measurements heading.
Length/Height of the baby at the 6-8 week HV review, suggested to be pulled through from the Measurements heading.

Feeding status of the baby at the 6-8 week HV review, suggested to be pulled through from the Feeding Status heading
    .

A list of examinations and assessments and their results carried out at the 6-8 week review
    .

Safety Alerts at the




















6-8 week HV Review., suggested to be pulled through from the Safety Alerts heading
      
    
    .
A list of Developmental Skills outcomes as per Developmental Skills heading.
This includes what information (including health promotional messages) and to whom it was given from the Information and Advice Given heading.

Summary of problems that require investigation or treatment. This would include significant examination findings which are likely to have relevance, yet are not a diagnosis, from the Problems and Issues heading.
Commentary to capture how mother and family are coping and any concerns about babies health or behaviour documented at the 6-8 week HV review.
The details of 1 Year review of child.

The date on which the 1 Year Review was recorded
    .
The location where the 1 Year Review was recorded.
The details of the professional performing the 1 Year Review (including name and role).

Weight of the baby at the 1 Year Review, suggested to be pulled through from the Measurements heading
    .
Examinations Findings, from the Examination Findings heading. This includes physical and developmental examinations and checks.
Feeding status of the baby at the 1 Year Review, suggested to be pulled through from the Feeding Status heading.
Household environment at the 1 Year Review, suggested to be pulled through from the Social Context heading.

Safety Alerts at the 1 Year Review, suggested to be pulled through from the Safety Alerts heading
    .
A list of Developmental Skills outcomes as per Developmental Skills heading.
If an Assessment is completed at this encounter, suggested to be pulled through from the Assessment Scales heading.
This includes what information (including health promotional messages) and to whom it was given from the Information and Advice Given heading.

Summary of problems that require investigation or treatment. This would include significant examination findings which are likely to have relevance, yet are not a diagnosis, from the Problems and Issues heading.

Commentary to capture how mother and family are coping and any concerns about babies health or behaviour documented at the 1 Year Review
    .

The details of 
      
    
    2 -2.5 Year Health and Development Review
The date on which the 2 -2.5 Year Review was recorded.
The location where the 2 -2.5 Year Review was recorded.
The details of the professional performing the 2 -2.5 Year Review (including name and role).
Weight of the baby at the 2 -2.5 Year Review, suggested to be pulled through from the Measurements heading.
Examinations Findings, from the Examination Findings heading. This includes physical and developmental examinations and checks.
Household environment at the 2 -2.5 Year Review, suggested to be pulled through from the Social Context heading.
Safety Alerts at the 2 -2.5 Year Review, suggested to be pulled through from the Safety Alerts heading.

A summary of the Early Years Assessment carried out by pre-school.
This includes what information (including health promotional messages) and to whom it was given from the Information and Advice Given heading.

Summary of problems that require investigation or treatment. This would include significant examination findings which are likely to have relevance, yet are not a diagnosis, from the Problems and Issues heading.

The details of child’s 
      
    
    School Entry Review.
The date on which the School Entry Review was recorded.
The location where the School Entry Review was recorded.
The details of the professional performing the School Entry Review (including name and role).
Weight of the child at the School Entry Review, suggested to be pulled through from the Measurements heading.
Household environment at the School Entry Review, suggested to be pulled through from the Social Context heading.

Safety Alerts at the School Entry Review, suggested to be pulled through from the Safety Alerts heading
    .
A list of Developmental Skills outcomes as per Developmental Skills heading.

A list of examinations and assessments carried out and the results

such as Vision and Screening .
If an Assessment is completed at this encounter, suggested to be pulled through from the Assessment Scales heading.
A summary of any information given by the school.
This includes what information (including health promotional messages) and to whom it was given from the Information and Advice Given heading.

Summary of problems that require investigation or treatment. This would include significant examination findings which are likely to have relevance, yet are not a diagnosis, from the Problems and Issues heading.
Commentary to capture how mother and family are coping and any concerns about the child's health or behaviour documented at the School Entry Review.

The details of Childs 
      
    
    Ad Hoc Review
The date in which the Ad Hoc Review was recorded.
The location where the Ad Hoc Review was recorded.
The details of the professional performing the Ad Hoc Review (including name and role).
Weight of the baby/child at the Ad Hoc Review, suggested to be pulled through from the Measurements heading.
Feeding status of the baby at the Ad Hoc Review, suggested to be pulled through from the Feeding Status heading.
A list of examinations and assessments carried out and the results.
Household environment at the Ad Hoc Review, suggested to be pulled through from the Social Context heading.
Safety Alerts at the Ad Hoc Review, suggested to be pulled through from the Safety Alerts heading.
A list of Developmental Skills outcomes as per Developmental Skills heading.
If an Assessment is completed at this encounter, suggested to be pulled through from the Assessment Scales heading.
This includes what information (including health promotional messages) and to whom it was given from the Information and Advice Given heading.

Summary of problems that require investigation or treatment. This would include significant examination findings which are likely to have relevance, yet are not a diagnosis, from the Problems and Issues heading.
Commentary to capture how mother and family are coping and any concerns about babies/child health or behaviour documented at the Ad Hoc Review.
